column4: I've mounted up a floppy.  Now, when I change disks do I have to unmount/remount it?  Since asking this the first time, I've written a script that unmounts it (if it's mounted at all) the remounts it and made a desktop icon that launches the script.  Is there a better way?
i would imagine that it is unmounted when you eject the floppy
no
ok, I've done it the right way I guess, just wondered if there were a "righter" way
by default there aren't any netfilter rules loaded
I want to make sure it's not causing trouble.
you can check if there are any rules loaded with iptables-save, but there shouldn't be any unless you added them
he's reading the libata wiki article (which is what I imagine the problem is)
what do you knwo about grub?
i don't know? i think a fair amount
ok.  I have ubuntu on the second drive, and the kernel is on the second partition.  grub numbers funny compared to fstab, and I'm not sure how that entry would look
probably (hd1,1)
http://rafb.net/p/6yLwZY21.html.  What do you think?  Do I need to have boot at the end of the centos grub file?
i think it should be (hd1,1)
that wasn't working either
what about the boot part?
oh, do you have a separate /boot ?
yes
remove the /boot from the kernel and initrd lines and change it to root=/dev/hda2
i think this might work: http://rafb.net/p/PPAogw54.html
you might just want to mount by UUID though
and change the hda1 to hdb1?  Ubuntu is on the second drive now.
or is it relative, and needs to be hda?
i'm not sure what the kernel will detect it as, so you have to try both hda and hdb (which is why mounting by UUID is a better idea)
